sentence: U.S. stocks were poised to open lower as weekly jobless claims unexpectedly rose, as companies reported mixed earnings, in many cases weighed down by the strong dollar, and after disappointing economic data out of the Eurozone and China.
The Markit Eurozone PMI showed growth edged lower at the start of Q2 while the HSBC flash China manufacturing PMI fell to a one-year low.
In the U.S., jobless claims in the week ended April 18 rose by 1,000 to 295,000, missing expectations for a drop to 286,000.
The consensus range was between 280,000 and 305,000, according to data compiled by Econoday.
At 9:45 a.m. the final Markit PMI manufacturing index for April is seen at 56.0 compared to 55.3 in March and within the consensus range between 55.5 and 56.4.
At 10;00 a.m., data on new home sales are expected to show a decline to 518,000 in March from 539,000 in February.
The consensus range is between 470,000 and 569,000.

In equities, consumer products giant Procter & Gamble ( PG ) dropped 1.5% in recent pre-market trade after reporting Q1 sales that missed estimates amid negative foreign exchange movements and divestments of brands.
Car maker General Motors ( GM ) fell 2.2% after Q1 missed forecasts while Dunkin' Brands ( DNKN ) was a bright spot, jumping 8.8% after Q1 EPS and revenue beat the Street's estimates.
